newsitem.title: USA: Radisys shares off on SEC request.
newsitem.headline: Radisys shares off on SEC request.

text.p: Shares of Radisys Corp fell sharply Friday after the company told analysts the Securities and Exchange Commission had requested documents related to the company's inventory accounting, analysts said.
The company, which makes embedded computer technologies, fell 13-1/8 or 22.8 percent to 44-3/8 in Nasdaq trade.

According to analystys, the company told them about the SEC request during a conference call late Thursday after Radisys had reported its fourth quarter results. A spokesman for Radisys did not return telephone calls.
According to analysts, the company said it had provided the requested information to the SEC and had not heard back from the agency.

In November, Bruce Taylor, a former vice president of operations sued the company alleging he uncovered a "significant discrepency in the financial records of Radisys" related to the reporting of the company's inventory.
The company responded by saying the lawsuit had no merit and it had not been contacted then by the SEC.

Word of the SEC request overshadowed the company's better than expected fourth quarter profit. On Thursday, Radisys reported a profit of $3.6 million or $0.46 a share for the fourth quarter, topping the First Call consensus of $0.42 a share. In the year ago quarter, Radisys reported a profit of $630,000 or $0.11 a share. Revenues for the quarter rose to $27.5 million from $10.6 million.
